title: 108_hr1026
content: The Act titled "Coastal Services and Performance Evaluation Act of 2003" includes provisions for amending the Coastal Zone Management Act of 1972, establishing policies, creating a Coastal Zone Management Fund, providing coastal services, reviewing performance, and authorizing appropriations for coastal zone management. It also includes amendments related to the Walter B. Jones Awards for Excellence in Coastal Zone Management, requirements for reports, technical corrections, and the development of coastal zone management outcome indicators and monitoring systems. SEC. 3. AMENDMENT OF COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT ACT OF 1972. Amendments to the Coastal Zone Management Act of 1972 are referenced in this Act. SEC. 4. POLICY. Section 303 (16 U.S.C. 1452) is amended to include "State and Federal fish" in paragraph (2)(J). SEC. 5. COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT FUND. SEC. 5. COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT FUND. Section 308 (16 U.S.C. 1456a) is amended to retain loan repayments for the Coastal Zone Management Fund and make them available for implementing the title. In subsection (b), paragraphs (2) and (3) are removed. SEC. 6. COASTAL SERVICES. Amends Section 310 to include coastal services, training, education, and technical support. The Secretary is responsible for conducting a program to support State coastal management programs, national estuarine reserves, and other entities involved in ocean and coastal resource management. The program includes training, education, technical assistance, and research to address regional and local concerns, including the unique needs of island States and territories. Coordination of activities is also required. The Secretary may receive assistance from other government agencies and individuals to carry out coastal management programs, research, and technical assistance. This assistance can be provided on a reimbursable basis and should not interfere with the primary duties of the assisting agencies. The Secretary can enter contracts with other Federal agencies and qualified individuals to carry out coastal management programs. Section 312 (16 U.S.C. 1458) is amended to require the Secretary to conduct a review of each coastal State's management program every 5 years. The review will assess the State's implementation and enforcement of the approved program, addressing coastal management needs, meeting outcome indicators, and adhering to grant terms. Additionally, there are amendments related to the Walter B. Jones Awards for Excellence in Coastal Zone Management. Section 314 (16 U.S.C. 1460) is amended to authorize a program for promoting excellence in coastal zone management through awards, including cash awards, research grants, and public ceremonies. The Secretary may select annually for an award under this section, and subsection (e) is repealed. SEC. 9. REPORTS. Section 316(a) (16 U.S.C. 1462(a)) is amended to remove certain clauses and subsection (c) is amended to require the Secretary to provide a coastal status report to Congress every 24 months, including an assessment of ecological status and trends of US marine resources. The amendment to Section 316(a) requires the Secretary to provide a coastal status report to Congress every 24 months, evaluating the ecological status and trends of US marine resources, including government performance measures and the adequacy of monitoring programs. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amends Section 318(a) to allocate funds for fiscal years 2004-2008 for section 310 and awards under section 314. SEC. 11. TECHNICAL CORRECTIONS. The Coastal Zone Management Act of 1972 is amended to make various changes, including updating terminology and punctuation. The Coastal Zone Management Act of 1972 is amended to update terminology and punctuation, such as changing "state's" to "State's" in reference to States of the United States. SEC. 12. Coastal Zone Management Outcome Indicators and Monitoring System. The Secretary of Commerce must submit a report to the Committee on Resources of the House of Representatives within 1 year after the enactment of the Act, identifying measurable outcome indicators for evaluating State coastal zone management programs. Additionally, within 2 years after the enactment of the Act, the Secretary must submit a report on coastal and marine monitoring, assessment, and information to the Committee on Resources. The Secretary of Commerce must submit a report to the Committee on Resources of the House of Representatives within 1 year after the enactment of the Act, identifying measurable outcome indicators for evaluating State coastal zone management programs. Within 2 years, a report on coastal and marine monitoring, assessment, and information must be submitted. The Secretary shall establish a national coastal zone management outcome monitoring and performance evaluation system within 3 years, using a common set of indicators. The Secretary must consult with coastal States and the public for input on reports under subsection (a). Consultation with States is required, and a public process for feedback from various entities is also mandated. To carry out this section, $1,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated for each of the fiscal years 2004, 2005, and 2006 for review and response to comments received on draft reports.
